title.narrative: Standing Up For Adolescents (SU4A)

description.narrative: Child marriages and teenage pregnancies remain high in Malawi. The country has one of the highest rates of child marriages in the world. UNICEF estimates that 9% and 46% are married by 15 and by 18 years old respectively. Apart from certain related harmful cultural practices, teenage pregnancies are one of the main causes of child marries. Teenage pregnancies remain high because of high unmet need for contraceptives, peer pressure and other harmful cultural practices like Kusasa fumbi (interpreted as shaking off the inexperience in sex by doing it) and kutomera (Some worthy community members choosing a girl child as a wife when she is still a toddler).

mailing-address.narrative: Amref Health Africa in Malawi P.O Box 30768 Capital City Lilongwe 3

description.narrative: Expenditures in Jan-June 2019 include direct and indirect programme costs made by Amref Malawi
Expenditures in jan-dec 2017 include direct and indirect programme costs made by Amref Malawi
Expenditures jan-dec 2018 include direct and indirect programme costs made by Amref Malawi

title.narrative: Quarterly evidence based advocacy meeting with stakeholders
Number of evidence based advocacy meetings condcuted with stakeholders.

description.narrative: A count of all advocacy meetings conducted with stakeholders in the district focusing on SRHR topics including CM, TP and other harmful cultural practices. During these meetings, count all attendees and disaggregate by gender and area of expertee

title.narrative: Documentation of case studies ans success stories with beneficieries
Number of case studies and success stories documented

description.narrative: A count of all case studies and success stories documented in the project

title.narrative: Orient ADC, VDC, and PTA members on prevention of teenage pregnancies, and child marriages and their effects on maternal morbidity and mortality.
Number of ADC, VDC and PTA members oriented on prevention of early pregnancies child marriages and their effects

description.narrative: A count of all community structures (ADC, VDC, PTA etc) members attending orientation meetings/workshops on prevention of early pregnancies, child marriages and theor effects disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: New ADC and VDC members were appointed and hence the orientation

title.narrative: Conduct dialogue sessions with traditional leaders and community members on SRHR.
Number of dialogue sessions cunducted with influencial learders and community members on SRHR issues

description.narrative: A count of all dialogue sessions conducted with influencial leaders (Chiefs, religios leaders, angaliba's and Anankugwi's) and other community members on SRHR issues affecting the communities.

title.narrative: Exchange visit to the Alternative Rites of Passage projects in Kenya and Tanzania (3 project team members, PM, PO & M&E)
Number of exchange visits conducted

description.narrative: A count of all exchange visits conducted in the project. These exchange visits shall be for project staff and other partners between YIDA and SU4A, including regional visits to Kenya for ARP

title.narrative: ADC, VDC and PTA members conduct interface meetings on SRHR issues targeting prevention of teenage pregnancies and child marriages.
Number of interface meetings conducted by ADC, VDC and PTA members on SRHR issues

description.narrative: A count of all interface meetings conducted a community structure on SRHR topics/issues.

title.narrative: Conduct open days to provide ASRHR messages on family life, calture and traditional pracrices, gender roles, human rights, gender equity, discrimination and sexual abuse etc)
Number of open days conducted on ASRHR topics

description.narrative: A count of all open days conducted in communities on SRHR topics.

title.narrative: Conduct operational research and situation analysis to generate evidence for advocacy.
Number of Reports and best practices generated

description.narrative: A count of all reports and best pracices generated in the project

title.narrative: Conduct open days to provide ASRHR messages on family life, calture and traditional pracrices, gender roles, human rights, gender equity, discrimination and sexual abuse etc)
Number of initiation graduation ceremonies supported (ARP)

description.narrative: A count of initiation graduation ceremonies. These are held after boy and gilrls successfully go through counselling in the initiation camps. During the gradutions, SRHR messeges will be given to the graduants to make informed decision regarding their sexual and reproductive health and rights

title.narrative: Train health care workers as youth CBDA
Number of out of school youths trained as youth CBDAs

description.narrative: Number of health care providers working with adolescents, number (of these) who received training to be Community Based Distribution Agents.

title.narrative: provide life skills training to adolescensts
Number of adolescent boys and girls trained in life skills.

description.narrative: This indicatior measures the number of adolescent boys and girls trained in life skills. These trainings include subjects like decision making, critical thinking, and making appropriate deciscion concerning their SRH life.

title.narrative: Establishing and or strengthening youth clubs
Number of (youth)clubs formed/and supported in the targeted communities

description.narrative: This indicator measures the number of in-school youth clubs formed in the communities with members of ages 10-24.

title.narrative: Train social workers to assist in counseling young girls in prevention of TP and CM
Number of social workers trained in counselling adolescent boys and girls on TP and CM

description.narrative: This indicator measures the number of social workers trained in counselling adolescents on TP and CM

title.narrative: Provide peer education on SRH to in and out school boys and girls
Number of boys and girls reached with SRHR messages disagregated by gender and age (10-19 and 20-24)

description.narrative: This indicator specificaly estimates all adolescents reached ith SRHR messages disaggregated by age (10-19, 20-24) and gender (male, female)

comment.narrative: 141 boys and 202 girls were 10-19 years and 91 boys and 97 girls were 20-24 years old
977 boys and 1095 girls were aged between 10 and 19

title.narrative: Provide peer education on SRH to in and out school boys and girls
Number of young people trained as peer educators on SRH issues that concern their lives. (disaggregated by age and gender)

description.narrative: This is a count of all young people (10-24) who have completed a training course in adolescent and youth sexual and reproductive health (AYSRH) peer education. An individual should only be counted after they have completed the training. Individuals that are mid-way through a training course should be counted in the next reporting period. Individuals attending more than one peer education training during a reporting period should be counted only once.

title.narrative: ADC members will have biannual exchange visits to share experiences and lessons on preventing TP, eliminating CM, kusasa fumbi and kutomera.
Number of biannual exchange visits done between ADC members (Experiences and lessons learned ducumented through case studies

description.narrative: This measures the number of exchange visits done to share experiences and lessons in the prevention of TP and CM in the YIDA and SU4A projects

title.narrative: Distribute contraceptives to adolescents
Number of adolescent youths (10-24) accessing contraceptives disaggregated by type

description.narrative: This measures the number of of youths (10-24) accessing contraceptives disaggregated by type

title.narrative: Support outreach clinics to provide (A)SRH services
Number of outreach clinics supported to provide (A)SRH services

description.narrative: This measures the number of outreach clinics supported to provide SRH services to adolescents

title.narrative: Conduct supportive supervision (follow up meetings) in all youth clubs.
Number of supportive supervision visits conducted by the program to the youth clubs to monitor activities

description.narrative: This measures the number of supervision visits to peer educators and youth clubs. This support supervision helps peer educatorsand youth clubs in the execution of their role.

title.narrative: Production of IEC materials and airing of radio jingles on ASRHR, CM, kusasa fumbi and kutomera
Number of IEC materials and radio jingles produced and distributed/aired respectively

description.narrative: This output indicator measures the number of IEC materails, including T shirts, flyers/posters, brochures/note books or banners/bill boards produced and distributed in the implementation area

title.narrative: Adolescent peer educators will conduct dialogue with fellow youths in youth clubs to address moral issues
Number of dialogue sessions conducted by adolescent peer educators with fellow youths in clubs

description.narrative: This output level indicator measures the number of dialogue sessions peer educators have with fellow youths in clubs

title.narrative: Conduct interface meetings targeting change of harmful cultural practice (such as kusasa fumbi and kutomela) and prevention of child marriages and teenage pregnancies
Number of interface meetings conducted with adolescents on harmful cultural practices and prevention of TP and CM

description.narrative: This output level indicator measures the number of interface meetings conducted. Interface meetings discuss issues affecting the youth and what the different players can do to mitigate such issues in order to ensure that adolescents have rights and make meaningful decision as to who and when to marry.

title.narrative: Increasing and or establishing service delivery points providing youth friendly health services
Number of established service delivery points providing youth friendly services
Health workers trained to provide adolescent and youth-friendly health services
Number of service providers/health staff trained in the delivery of adolescent and Youth-Friendly Services (YFS)
Train champions in dispelling harmful cultural practices
Number of champions (change agents) trained/oriented on harmful cultural practices fueling TPs and CMs
Conduct open days to provide ASRHR messages on family life, calture and traditional pracrices, gender roles, human rights, gender equity, discrimination and sexual abuse etc)
Number of men and women (25+ years) reached with SRHR messages disagregatred by gender and age
